2.long:
All four elements join together in this room, fusing in an intricate
pattern.  The element rooms lie to the north, south, east, and west.
In the middle of the room is a stairway leading down.

3.long:
The walls of this room seem to be sharply cut from the surrounding
stone, revealing the brown earth beneath the chipped white paint.  The
floor here has been crushed and broken, leaving you standing on dirt.
You can exit to the north.

4.long:
This room is carved into the white surrounding stone in a hemisphere,
with a very high ceiling and light gray floor tiles.  The wind in this
room swirls and blows around you, keeping you constantly off balance.
You may exit to the south.

5.long:
This red room flickers and glows from some internal source, causing
shadows to jump randomly around the room.  There is also a barely
audible roaring sound that seems to come from all around you.  You can
leave to the east.

6.long:
The walls in this room are painted a delicate shade of cyan, with
flowing swirls of darker blue.  You are filled with a sense of peace in
this room.  The only exit is to the west.

100.long:
This cavernous area consists of the internals of a giant whale!  You
are periodically shoved around the room by the whale's movements, and
you can see a pile of something being slowly digested to the south,
where the stomach narrows.  Light comes in through a small hole in the
ceiling that appears to be the whale's blowhole.  You can exit north,
towards the whale's mouth.
100.item: lying near a very large rib.

101.long:
You're in the closed mouth of a huge whale.  A bit of light comes in
between the whale's teeth as it opens its lips periodically to eat
some hapless water creature.  However, the walls of teeth remain
closed, barring your escape.  You can exit to the south, where the
whale's stomach widens.

193.long:
Twin columns of fire rise before you, each a raging pillar of flame.
The heat on your face and skin is palpable, and you think twice about
passing into the Realm of Fire.  Through the flames, you can see a
distorted, hellish vision of a barren landscape.  A region of vast
desert, overshadowed by ashen skies, and finally dominated by an
enormous, ebon volcano.  Just beyond the gateway, a rough black road
stretches to the horizon.  You can follow this road west, or head back
toward Crossroads, to the east.

194.long:
The charcoal sky lends a gloomy quality to this desolate place.  The
ground is rocky here, and completely without moisture.  The air itself
is dry, and seems to draw the water right out of you.  Regarding your
surroundings, you wonder about the type of life which might thrive in
this sort of environment.  To the east, a short distance, is the gate
marking the beginning of this Realm, and the city of Crossroads is a
ways beyond that.  Movement to the north and south is constrained by
the walls of rock which make up this gulch, but the desert opens up
farther to the west.

195.long:
Waves of heat rise from the desert floor, giving the impression of
water near the horizon.  The sweltering air is still and languid, not
even granting you the pleasure of a small breeze.  Silence hangs in
the air like a shroud, lending a solemn atmosphere to this cheerless
place.  Large regions of dry, cracked, desert terrain lay to the north
and south.  A journey east leads into a small gulch, or you can venture
west on the road into still more desert.

196.long:
The road begins to slope downwards here, eventually meeting the edge
of the canyon.  The city of Avernus is just visible on the other side.
Passage over the canyon seems to have been made possible by way of a
slender rope bridge.  The canyon extends a good distance north and
south, and the bridge appears to be the only easy way across.  You can
reach the bridge just to the west, follow the road east toward the
beginning of the Realm, or explore the desert which parallels the
canyon to the north and south.

197.long:
The slender bridge spans the canyon from east to west, more than a
thousand feet above the rocky floor.  Although the heat is maddening,
you are suddenly glad for the absence of a breeze.  The view of the
canyon from here is spectacular, although mixed with slight vertigo.
The walls are decorated with hues of red and orange strata.  The sides
of the canyon strangely copy each other in every major twist and turn,
almost making it look as if some enraged god had torn the land apart.
197.item: where it isn't supposed to be.  Please notify the SysOp.

198.long:
This room is filled with bookshelves, which are in turn unsurprisingly
filled with books.  Most of the volumes are similar and relatively
new, probably used by scribes for recording the ongoing history of the
Realm.  A few of the tomes, however, are dusty and distinct.  In the
center of the room rests a large, uncomfortable looking wooden table,
at which a monk and an initiate are seated.  The east wall of the room
is lit up by a roaring fire, the orange glow diffusing into the solid
obsidian wall.  The main hall of the temple is back to the west, behind
a heavy grey curtain.

199.long:
This chamber is used by the Brotherhood to ponder the various aspects
and meanings of their Element.  Many new insights into the nature of
fire are stumbled upon by students every day in this room.  In the
center of the chamber is a pit of bright orange coals, small flames
dancing rapidly across their surfaces.  Surrounding the pit are various
other demonstrations of the fire element.  A small pool of magma
seethes and boils on the far side of the room.  To your right, an
initiate is working with various metals and minerals, experimenting
with each in a nearby furnace.  Off to the left, a single jet of flame
erupts from a small hole in the floor, rising to the height of a man.
The monks maintain these captive examples of the Element through
taxing magic effort, but consider it well worth their time as a means
of instruction.  You can leave the room to the east, through a heavy
curtain.

200.long:
This room is immense, and must take up most of the area inside the
temple.  Huge tapestries and paintings adorn the walls, portraying
varied historic and spiritual events.  The obsidian surfaces do not
reflect much light, but the room is kept bright by hundreds of candles,
set about its perimeter.  The musky smell of incense drifts around the
room.  On the north wall is a shrine erected to Kalok, God of Fire.
Occasionally you will see a monk doing his daily chores or praying
silently.  You can reach smaller areas of the temple behind curtains to
the east and west, or you may leave the temple by the south exit.

201.long:
You are on the bottom steps of the entrance to the Temple of Fire.  The
temple is a pyramidal structure, fashioned entirely from jet black
obsidian.  The craftsmanship of the structure is exceptional.  The
individual pieces, if indeed there are any, fit together seamlessly.
The builders were no doubt extremely proficient in magic.  Two brightly
flaming torches are mounted on either side of the north entrance,
inviting entry.

202.long:
You are sitting at one of the tables in a local pub.  The walls are
decorated with unusual objects, ranging from a handmade dragonscale
shield to the bleached skulls of various monsters.  Torchlight casts
flickering shadows throughout the smoky room.  At the other end of the
table, two monks are passing the time drinking and playing a game of
chance.  The main counter is a quick trip to the west.

203.long:
You're seated at an old, but sturdy wooden table in a local pub.  In
the table surface are carved the initials of some anonymous drunk.
You notice with no surprise that the temple abbot is here, drinking
and laughing and generally making a spectacle of himself.  An
uncomfortable looking monk sitting across from him has apparently
gotten stuck with the job of being his drinking partner.  On the far
wall, lit by torchlight, gleams a ruby set into the pommel of a large
sword.  The main counter is a short walk to the east.

204.long:
You are standing in the local pub.  The air is filled with smoke, and
the raucous laughter of the patrons.  The tavern is fashioned out of
large blocks of pumice and other lava rock, and is lit by torches set
into depressions in the walls.  The owner, Black, looks up from behind
the bar and nods politely to you as you enter.  Black is perhaps the
best known man in all the Realm of Fire.  He takes care of shipments of
supplies for the city, heads the local council, and is just generally
the most amiable guy you are likely to run across.  You can purchase
drinks over the counter here, and there are tables to the east and west
at which you can relax with a brew.

205.long:
You are standing in the middle of the city square, looking around the
city.  The hustle and bustle of activity is a welcome change from the
disconcerting quiet of the desert.  To the north, you see the jet
black pyramid which is the Temple of Fire, home for the monks which
both study and serve this Element.  To the south is the city pub.  The
people of Fire love their drink, and you should not be surprised to
find many of the temple monks enjoying their evenings with one of the
bartender's special brews.  To the east, a rope bridge leads over a
canyon and into a desolate desert, and to the city road continues to
the west.

206.long:
This part of the city is where the few permanent inhabitants of the
town choose to live.  A number of huts and small buildings line the
borders of the road.  Occasionally, someone walking by will shoot a
suspicious glance your way, scowl irritably, and disappear quickly
into a house.  The road continues into an entirely black, barren
region toward the south and west, extending all the way to Khalas.  The
change from east to west in the color of the land is startling, but
understandable in light of the nearing proximity of the volcano.  You
can make your way through the buildings to an overlook of the canyon to
the north, or head back east to the city square.

207.long:
This region, although resembling a desert, is almost completely black.
Black rocks and sand stretch out to the north, south, and apparently
as far west as the volcano.  In many spots, loose sand has completely
covered the road, causing you to rely entirely upon your sense of
direction to keep on the path.  With both the leaden skies above and
dark terrain below, this area easily creates a disquieting feeling of
despair.  You can trek back toward the city to the east, venture west
nearer the base of Khalas, or journey farther into this wasteland to
the north and south.

208.long:
Black terrain stretches out in every direction, the road beneath your
feet the only sign of previous habitation.  Black, porous rock extends
north into the distance, eventually meeting with one of the steep
mountainsides common to this Realm.  To the west, the volcano rises
into the sky, just opposite a small ravine.  South is a black gulch,
likely fashioned by the high volume of lava which once passed through
this area.  The drop into the gulch is too steep from here, but it
looks possible to reach it by circling around to the southeast and
then doubling back west.  Eastward, the road continues through this
void, eventually passing through the city of Avernus.

209.long:
This small gorge is clearly the result of a past lava flow.  The walls
and floor are black and made of volcanic rock, but it is apparent that
this area was at one time just an ordinary mesa.  The road seems to
continue into this area, but it is in bad condition, crumbling and
splitting from age and use in many areas.  Comparing conditions to the
east, you wonder if the road might have had the advantage of magical
enhancement up until this point.  You can journey through the chasm and
to the base of Khalas to the west, or head back toward the city to the
east.

210.long:
This side of the volcano is steep and treacherous.  A large rock face,
colored with pale shades of orange and yellow, rises straight up into
the somber sky.  Upon further inspection, you can see how the lava
missed this area during the last eruption.  Streams of black rock came
instead from the north and south, merged, and headed eastward.  It
seems likely that either of these black paths will prove to be a valid
way up this side of the volcano.
210.item: at the base of the cliff.

211.long:
The cave walls are made of brittle, chalky orange rock, and they extend
several feet into the cliff.  It seems the flows of molten rock leave
this place alone; a good place to remember in case Khalas should become
suddenly active.  In the center of the grotto are the remains of a
recent fire, an indication that this place might be used as a resting
stop on trips to or from the volcano.  Just outside, narrow ledges head
off the steep face to the north and south.

212.long:
You are on a narrow ledge which juts out a small distance over the
cliff face.  The rock here crumbles easily and you make a point to
watch your step.  From here, you can see Avernus far below and to the
west, dwarfed by the adjacent canyon.  The temperature is much cooler
here, than below, almost pleasant.  The white mists which permanently
hang around the crater swirl above your head, a promise that it will
become cooler still toward the top.  To the west, toward the crater,
one black line of earth separates into two smaller streaks of black,
one heading north and the other south, evidence of a lava flow which
just missed this area.

213.long:
The walk up until this point was cool and refreshing, but here, at the
edge of the crater rim, the heat pushes the limits of your tolerance.
Surveying the inside of the crater you can see fountains of bright
orange and yellow magma occasionally shoot through the grey skin of
partially cooled molten rock.  Sulfurous fumes rise from below, strong
and hot, but dissipate quickly in the strong breeze coming from behind.
Off to the east, white mists obscure your vision of the city of
Avernus, but you are able to see the other elemental Realms far off in
the distance.  The domain of Earth can be recognized by a large castle,
towering atop a lone hill which is set into a carpet of green trees.
Air is easily pinpointed by a giant rainbow, strung across the heavens
over majestic clouds and floating islands.  The Realm of Water is by
far the easiest to spot, though, by its endless expanse of blue ocean
heading out from a sheltered bay to meet the horizon.  Paths lead down
from the crater rim in all directions.
213.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

214.long:
The soil here is soft and even somewhat moist, but still retains the
black color of volcanic influence.  A few shrubs and weeds are having
luck surviving around here, helped along in part, by the humid mists
which surround the crater.  The top of the volcano is a gentle climb to
the east, and you can also go down the slope to the far side.  Other
areas around this side are just to the north and south.

215.long:
Shrubs and other plants grew here a short time ago, but have since been
charred and turned to ashes by a recent fire.  The air here is slightly
cooler here than it is at the base, and the heat should continue to
recede if you climb higher toward the top.  You can reach the base of
the far side of Khalas with a short climb down this slope, or you can
explore this side of the volcano further to the north and south.

216.short: ...You're at the far end of Khalas.
216.long:
A faint stench of sulfur is coming from an opening in the east side of
the volcano.  The opening visibly continues for a distance into the
blackened mountainside before it branches off in another direction.
A lava flow, and a recent one at that, spilled out of this opening and
flowed off to the north and south, likely the cause of the fire on the
slopes above.  When the magma expands and erupts, you realize uneasily,
this will be the first place it streams out.  You can follow the frozen
lava rivers to the north and south, climb up the slopes toward the
crater rim, or hazard the tunnel to the east.

217.long:
A recent lava flow has come in from the north, covering this area in
smooth, hardened magma.  This black river was undoubtedly the origin of
the fire which swept up the dry grass on this side of the volcano.  The
river eventually cut into one of the steep mountainsides to the west,
and disappeared underground.  A very narrow trail to the east circles
around out of sight toward the south side of the volcano.  It looks
safe enough to travel on, as long as you don't meet anyone coming the
other way.  You can also proceed up the slopes of Khalas, or head to
the north, toward the source of the lava flow.

218.long:
A large fire recently swept through this place, leaving only blackened
grass and the charred remains of shrubs and bushes in its wake.  The
fire doesn't seem to have gone any higher, though.  The sparse plants
toward the top were probably unable to carry the blaze, but it does
look like the fire reached farther north.  A footpath takes off to the
east, tracing a circuitous route around the south side of the volcano.
A climb further up or down this side of Khalas is reasonably easy, and
you can also head off into another badly burned section to the north.

219.short: ...You're on the southwest side of Khalas.
219.long:
A long, but narrow crack in the ground of the volcano begins here and
runs northeast up to the crater rim.  The rest of this gentle incline
is filled with the loose lava rock that is so popular with this region.
Scanning the horizon, you can see the grey, featureless mountains
which surround the volcano.  Their unremarkable countenances blend
easily into the charcoal skies, giving the impression of one great,
grey void.  A climb to the top of the volcano is feasible from the
areas to the north and east, as is a climb down the far slope, or a
journey south toward a high cliff.

220.short: ...You're on the south side of Khalas.
220.long:
The air is nearly cool and pleasant at this height and just above
you, foggy white mists announce the presence of the volcano's crater.
The rank smell of sulfur is present, but the wind is blowing lightly,
and feels good on your face, somewhat making up for it.  Directly to
the north, a hike through some unusual lava formations will take you to
the rim.  Additionally, you can travel east and west to those sections
of Khalas' surface, or head farther south, down to the top of a high
cliff.

221.short: ...You're on the southeast side of Khalas.
221.long:
A major lava flow, still mostly intact and unbroken, has swept through
here from the northwest and down the steep east side.  Looking toward
the origin of the flow, you can see that this is only one of two
branches of lava which split from a main flow just before reaching a
high ledge.  Going north will take you to that ledge, and there is yet
another cliff you can reach to the south.  Climbing down through the
lava flow, using the irregularities of the cooled rock as a purchase,
seems another possibility, or you can head around the other side of
the volcano to the west.

222.long:
A river of lava once flowed swiftly through this area, once probably
part of the steep face to the north, but was eroded by the molten rock
into merely a sharp incline.  You are halfway up the ascent, perched on
solid hand and foot holds.  The lava rock is chalky and brittle, and
you have been having some difficulty gaining traction on this steep
angle, but this is a good stopping position.  The grade continues both
up to the top of the cliff, and down to the base of the volcano.  Also,
a short distance away, a ledge begins and heads north into a depression
in the cliff.
222.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

223.long:
A torrent of lava once poured down the side of this cliff, eating into
the cliff rock as it flowed, slowly wearing the bluff down from a
vertical drop to a sharp, but manageable angle.  The molten rock then
appears to have flowed out the only available path to the north.  The
flow has since been broken into pieces by wear and weather, but you are
getting the hang of walking on it.  It looks like a rough climb up the
flow, but feasible with a good amount of effort.  To the north, you can
follow the black path around to the base of the cliff.

224.long:
A veritable waterfall of lava once cascaded down this side of the
bluff.  The flow has since been broken into large sized pieces by heat
and local inhabitants, but not before it took a good chunk of the side
of the cliff with it.  Once probably a vertical drop, this side of the
east face is a now a manageable grade.  As soon as the flow got to this
point, it was apparently guided by the surrounding cliff walls toward
the south, leaving a black path which you can easily follow.  Also,
an ascent up the incline of lava looks attainable, but not without
breaking a healthy sweat.

225.long:
A deluge of molten rock must have hastily flowed through this area,
once probably a section of the chalky cliff to the north.  The flow
doubtlessly cut away the previously vertical rock into merely a sharp
ascent.  The ground here is steep and rocky, but you have got a firm
hand and foot hold on stable rocks.  You notice a ledge, to your south,
which heads south and eventually into what might be a small cave.  The
incline continues both up to the top of the bluff, and down to the base
of the volcano.
225.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

226.short: ...You're on the northeast side of Khalas.
226.long:
This place is fairly high up on the east side of the mountain.  The top
of the volcano is just to the southwest, with a steep grade of lava
rock dropping below you.  Pumice is everywhere, and the surrounding
regions tell something of a story about the jagged rocks.  Toward the
crater rim, you can see that a huge, single stream of molten rock had
been flowing in the direction of the overhanging cliff directly to the
south.  The cliff being too high to reach, the lava changed course
before it could get there and split into two separate channels.  One of
them came this way, and headed over and down a steep cliff which, as
the magma cut itself a smooth path, gradually eroded into the incline
you are standing above.  The other one vanished to the south, but
assumably had much the same effect as this branch did.  A climb down
the incline, taken slowly, is possible, as is a journey to the high
face just south of here.  Other areas of the volcano are accessible to
the north and west.

227.long:
The air is cool and slightly humid.  The hike south to the crater rim,
will become even more so if the foggy white mists encompassing the top
of the volcano are any indication.  The ground is dark, but filled with
soil instead of the usual lava rock.  This place even boasts of a few
shrubs from spot to spot.  To the west is the gentle slope of the far
side of Khalas, and east is a high bluff overlooking the city far
below.  The north, a trail winds slowly down the north side of
Khalas and out of sight.

228.short: ...You're on the northwest side of Khalas.
228.long:
Jets of scalding hot air occasionally shoot from circular openings in
the ground here, as the volcano releases internal pressure.  The area
is thus predictably warm, and filled with the pungent smell of sulfur.
From this point, you can begin a climb down the far side of Khalas,
head north down this side of the mountain, or reach the other sides of
the volcano to the east and south.

229.long:
The blackened remains of burned vegetation crumble under your feet as
you walk through this area.  Soot and ashes are all that remain of a
large fire which blazed through here, destroying the few plants and
grasses that had managed to spring up.  The region to the south is much
like this one, also black and charred from the destructive effects of
the fire.  A gentle descent down this side to the base of the volcano
is easily made, as is a trek upwards, closer to the crater.

230.short: ...You're at the west base of Khalas.
230.long:
A relatively new flow of magma recently entered from the south, filling
this entire area in porous, hardened lava.  This frozen stream of
molten rock must have originated the fire which consumed the entire
west side of the volcano.  Then apparently, it having no where else to
go, the heated river cut into a mountainside just west of here and
vanished below ground.  You can start up toward the top of Khalas from
this point, or follow the lava flow south, to its source.

231.short: ...You're on the north side of the volcano.
231.long:
Bubbling pools of grey mud occupy much of this area, filling the air
with an almost overpowering smell of sulfurous gas.  From time to time
a large bubble will burst near you, spraying your legs with mud.  A
footpath circles around to the east, heading around to that side of
the volcano.  Alternately, a trek northward will take you farther down
the volcano's north side.  Other areas of Khalas lay south.
231.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

232.long:
This area is nearly a natural sauna.  Hot steam pours from several
openings in the black volcanic rock, hanging in the air for a short
time before dissipating entirely.  Many of these crevices descend a
short way into the ground, and the surrounding rock on the sides are
drenched with moisture.  The steam vents to the north are wide and
numerous enough that it is impossible to get through that area without
being seriously burned.  To the south, a trail zigzags toward the top
and out of sight.  A venture to the east or west into other areas on
this side of Khalas is also possible.

233.short: ...You're on the north side of the volcano.
233.long:
Geysers of white steam rise from gaps in the lava rock.  They billow
out into the open air for a few seconds before eventually dissipating.
Walking through this area is like getting a natural steam bath, and your
clothes and skin become quickly covered with moisture.  To the north and
east, these thermal vents become even larger and more dense, limiting
safe movement in that direction.  You can go south and climb up farther
toward the top, or make your way through this steaming area to the west.

234.long:
This primitive dwelling is small and modest.  Improvised shelves
stock many unusual objects, including one large jar full of glowing
fireflies.  The center of the room holds a sturdy wooden table,
clean except for what appears to be the gruesome remains of last
night's dinner.  Off to the side of the table, tucked underneath
another shelf, is a simple bed.
234.item: on the floor of the hut.

235.short: ...You're on a ledge, outside a hovel.
235.long:
At the far east end of this ledge sits a smallish hut, dwarfed by the
high walls rising to the south, and yet at the same time precariously
perched on the edge of a high drop off.  Quite a scenic view, but you
for some reason, you just can't imagine building a home here.  The
shack has been fashioned entirely out of rock and mud, but looks
reasonably sturdy to you.  The structure has no windows or door, but
only a small opening in the wall to the east.  You can go inside the
makeshift building or follow the ledge back toward the west.

236.short: ...You're at the far north side of Khalas.
236.long:
The side of the mountain ends here abruptly, almost without warning,
and becomes a series of high ledges and dropoffs the rest of the way
down to the base.  To the east, a small trail heads down onto the
nearest ledge and curves behind a large rock wall, vanishing from
sight.  The only other exit from here is to head south, gradually
climbing toward the crater.

237.short: ...You're on the south side of Khalas.
237.long:
Past eruptions mostly avoided this region, leaving the ground free of
the blackened landscape so prominent over the rest of the volcano.
You are standing atop a chalky, cream colored cliff.  This bluff towers
over the grey landscape below, and you feel a faint sense of vertigo.
To the west, a path meanders down the cliff and circles out of sight
toward that side of the volcano.  North will take you farther up this
small southern region, and the precipice stretches on to the east.

238.long:
A steep bluff rises far above the nondescript lowlands below.  Here, at
the top of the cliff, a light breeze is blowing.  The air at this
altitude is already reasonably cool, and the breeze makes it a great
place to momentarily escape the heat of the rest of the element.  The
bluff spans farther to the east and west, or you can trek straight up
to the crater rim by heading directly north.
238.item: near the edge of the cliff.

239.short: ...You're on the south side of Khalas.
239.long:
This cliffside escaped the blackened lava rock which lies strewn about
much of the rest of the volcano.  Looking northward, you can see it
only barely escaped at that.  A large river of magma was heading
this way, but swerved around to the east side of Khalas at the last
minute.  Turning your gaze south, down the cliff, you idly wonder how
hard a river of lava would hit, having fallen all the way to the
bottom.  You can leave this place to the north, which will take you
near the east side of Khalas, or back to the west, where this precipice
continues.

240.long:
This small walkway is bordered by high, vertical walls to the north and
east, and a long drop over the edge to the south.  In the wall to the
east is a small tunnel which leads off into the rock.  It appears to
continue for a short distance, but it becomes too dark to tell much
after that.  A breeze flowing easily through the opening assures that
the passage connects to somewhere.  You can chance the tunnel, or
continue along the ledge to the west.

241.long:
A high cliff wall rises nearly straight up to the north of you, and the
edge of another long drop begins just to the south, leaving you one of
two directions to go on this ledge.  Your path is blocked, however, by
an enormous giant snake, which is resting immobile on the ledge.

242.long:
This rocky shelf is bordered on the north and south sides by cliff
walls which extend up and down a great distance.  This ledge continues
off to the east, or you can opt to follow the ledge to the west, as it
narrows and curves around to the far side of the volcano.  Strewn all
about this place are bits of dry, dead skin and hand-sized scales.

243.long:
This black iron staircase leads up and down into the darkness as far as
you can see.  You worked up a good sweat reaching this middle point,
and it is thankfully somewhat cool on this square platform.  Nothing at
all is visible in the darkness beyond the stairs.  The black void is,
however, anything but silent and the air is filled with the continual
shrieks and screams of unseen phantoms.  The stairs continue up and
down through the darkness.
243.item: where it isn't supposed to be.  Please notify the SysOp.

244.long:
This is the bottom of the longest flight of stairs you have ever
encountered.  They extend up and into the darkness seemingly forever,
and the climb thrills you about as much as the screams you can hear
echoing in the surrounding darkness.  This platform extends farther to
the north where it meets an enormous iron portcullis.  The huge gate
appears, strangely, not to be attached to anything but resting upright
on the stairs.  What is keeping it up is uncertain, but it is solid
enough that only a fire giant might be able to lift it.

262.long:
Coarse, black sand covers the ground.  There are no plants anywhere in
this area; even the rugged cactus is apparently unable to grow here.
The creatures that inhabit these parts, if any do at all, must be
anything but the regular desert variety.  With a gulp, you realize that
in this grey and black domain, you probably stand out to them like a
beacon at nighttime.  This wasteland continues to the north and west,
and more regular desert is off to the east.

263.long:
The earth beneath your feet is hard and unyielding.  No vegetation
seems to be able to grow in this black, cracked earth, and lack of it
gives the illusion that this open plain extends forever.  Despair is a
common sentiment in this humorless place, and you are anxious to move
on.  To the east, a very large canyon runs north as far as the eye can
see.  Although it is not visible, the main road should be present just
to the north, or you can travel into rockier ground to the west.

264.long:
This is the north most part of the wide ledge which hangs over the
canyon floor, supporting all of Avernus.  The soil here is very black,
covered with the mineral rich remnants of ancient lava flows.  The city
hasn't grown large enough to need this area for much, and has generally
left it alone, with the exception of one large plaque overlooking the
canyon a few feet away.  The city road is off to the south, and this
dark ground continues to the west.

265.long:
Jet black sand, coarse as gravel, covers the ground.  Plants and the
usual smattering of desert creatures are nowhere around.  The extra
heat rising from the ground is a sizeable annoyance, and you want to be
soon on your way out of this barren parody of a desert.  This wasteland
continues to the west, becoming rockier, and to the east, a canyon
begins its long trek to the south.

266.long:
This is a rocky area, covered with jagged lava rocks.  Walking through
this area is made especially difficult by the brittle nature of the
porous rocks, many of them breaking under your feet.  Entire mountains
of these rocks rise up to the north and west, but they are too steep to
climb.  You can continue through this barren, black region to the south
and west.

267.long:
Fast cooling lava from a past eruption has made the ground in this
place smooth and shiny.  Wrinkles appear in this flow of solid rock,
much like the top of a fast flowing river, and in some parts of the
flow, sheets of solid obsidian can be found.  Looking toward the
source of the lava, to the west, the flow stops before it reaches
the volcano.  Much of the heated rock must have passed underground
before appearing into the open air and cooling here.  This black
wasteland continues in all directions, and the main road, while not
visible, should be just to the south.

268.long:
The rocky remains of past lava flows are strewn about this place.
Brittle, porous rocks are everywhere, and walking over them is a
special treat for your already tired legs.  The air here has a
pungent, unpleasant odor.  Perhaps the absence of plants is taking
its effect on the air, or maybe it is some strange mineral content in
the rocks, but something sure doesn't smell right.  A small chasm
limits movement to the east, but more of this cheery territory is to
the north, south, and west.

269.long:
A few feet away from you is a circular depression in the black ground,
through which is boiling what appears to be grey mud.  Every now and
then, a large bubble of gas will rise up through the heated mud and pop
on the surface, sending bits of grey goo everywhere.  A very strong
smell of sulfur is almost making you choke, making the north, east,
and south exits look suddenly attractive.

270.long:
The mountains rising above you to the south and west strangely show no
traces of the black rocks all around you, but with some exploration,
you find a lava tube set into the side of a mountain which explains
the oddity.  The lava tube has been mostly closed by successive
layers of lava cooling on top of each other, but there is still enough
room, at least at this point, to head into it.  A slight breeze coming
out of the tunnel at least assures that the other end of it connects
somewhere.  More of this blackened landscape is reachable to the north
and east, or you can try and head through the tunnel to the west.

271.long:
Steep walls of solid black rise up on either side of you.  Shortly to
the west is a lavafall which was cooled and frozen solid.  The river
of lava must have headed from there to the east and cut this black
gulch as it proceeded.  The pumice here has remained mostly intact,
breaking only into very large chunks which are easy to walk on.  The
only exit is to the east.

272.long:
Strange mounds of lava lie all around, like molten boulders.  Small
jets of molten rock must have erupted here from an underground flow,
powered by trapped volcanic gasses.  A few feet away, the lava from one
very large formation continues quite a distance to the east.  Steep
mountainsides to the north and west limit movement, but the main road
is just to the south, or you can follow a smooth lava flow to the east.

273.long:
Orange glows emanating from the south and east light up this cave.  The
walls are smooth and black and slightly rounded, evidence of a major
lava flow through this place.  A strong, very hot breeze is blowing
through here and out the west exit, toward open air.  The sickly smell
of sulfur is inescapable.  You can leave this tropical paradise to the
west, head south into an adjoining cavern, or chance the increasing
heat to the east.

274.long:
The smooth, lava formed walls are lit by an orange glow coming from a
small tunnel to the east, but to the touch, they feel hot enough to
glow all by themselves.  You can go through the tunnel to the east or
follow the stream of hot air running through here north to a larger
cavern.

275.long:
This room is a continuation of the cavern to the west, but the entire
south wall has opened up into a giant reservoir of molten rock.  In
close, here, the lava is relatively quiescent, but farther out it
bubbles and boils violently.  Riding on top of the lake like icebergs,
are large chunks of hardened rock.  A few of these slabs occasionally
pass enough to the shore for you to jump onto them, although you can't
think of a good reason why you'd want to try.

276.short: ...You're on a rocky shore, near a lake of fire.
276.long:
A rocky passage heads off into the north wall of this large cavern.
The entrance to this tunnel has been smoothed and decorated with
strange runes and other patterns, making you wonder if the Brotherhood
of Fire use and maintain this place for some purpose.  Apart from the
tunnel, the only other way out of here is by chancing a ride on the
fire sea.

277.long:
This area is lit by orange glows coming from the south and east.  There
are holders set into the rock which seem to have been used for burning
incense.  That, and some globs of wax on the floor suggest that this
room was used for meditation.  To the south, an ornately carved opening
marks the beginning of a tunnel back to the lake of fire.  To the east,
where this chamber continues, a small pool of brightly glowing orange
magma has broken through the floor.
277.item: on the floor of the chamber.

278.long:
This room is fantastically hot.  The walls on either side of the magma
come close to the pool, and one wrong step trying to get by it could
prove deadly.  Several skeletons surround the edge of the red hot
cauldron, making you wonder with a smirk if the heat was too much
for them.  To the east and west are other sections of this long
passage.
278.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

279.long:
This chamber is mostly empty, save for a few beds set against the north
wall.  An orange glow, cast by areas to the west and south, dimly
lights the room.  To the south, an opening carved in runes and other
patterns marks the beginning of a tunnel which leads to the lake of
fire.  To the west, this passage leads to a glowing pool of magma.

280.short: ...You're on a rocky shore, near a lake of fire.
280.long:
A squarish, black passage leads off into the north wall.  The opening
around the entrance to the passage is decorated with strange symbols,
and you can sense the residual tingle of some magical spell.  It is
very likely that the Brotherhood of Fire uses and maintains this place
for some reason.  Other than this entrance, the only other exit is to
hitch a ride on a slab of rock floating in the fire lake.

281.short: ...You're on the edge of a fire lake.
281.long:
This place is a very long way from the entrance on the far side.
Should Khalas decide to erupt, well, at least you will have a great
view, for a few seconds.  One end of a lava tube starts here and heads
east into the cavern wall, but is blocked by a blazing wall of flames.
The combined heat of the sweltering lava and this fiery wall is almost
making you unconscious, but you see there are no easy exits out of
here.  The only marginally sane way out seems to be to catch another
ride on the next passing chunk of rock which floats by.

282.long:
Fire surrounds and engulfs you.  Waves of heat rock you back and forth,
and flames lick your skin.  Fire spirits are at play, whisking around
the room in celebration, but the same sorcery which shields you from
the flames also keeps you safe from the spirits' mischieviousness.  This
room is hot, but not unbearable or really even uncomfortable.  Looking
at yourself, you see with some surprise that you and your possessions
are partially transparent, ostensibly from magical protection.  You can
exit out of the fire to the south or west.
282.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

283.long:
Human skeletons decorate the floor and walls of this smooth tunnel,
setting you on your guard.  These white remains have been carefully
strung across spikes and pegs in the wall as grisly decorations.  The
foul stench of something other than the human remains, but just as
revolting, is present here.  The lava tube continues to the south, or
you can enter blazing fires to the north.

284.long:
This smooth lava tube extends to the north and south.  To the north,
the tunnel extends out of sight, but to the south, extending to the
ceiling, stands a large statue of a demon, arms crossed across its
chest.  Just beyond the statue is a room completely filled with
blazing fire.  The only way to reach the flames to the south is to go
directly under the legs of the statue.  The north exit is looking
better and better.

285.long:
This room is an open furnace.  Fire dances up from the floor to the
ceiling, covering the entire room.  Strangely enough, the heat from the
room does not bother you, nor do the flames harm you or your things in
any way.  Your protection even manages to ward away the arrant spirits
of fire inhabiting this inferno.  Another strange effect of the magical
shield you notice when looking at yourself.  You and your possessions
are partially transparent, allowing the fire and flames to pass right
through your form, harmlessly.  You can leave this place to the north
or west.
285.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

286.short: ...You're on the edge of a fire lake.
286.long:
This rocky area borders a great reservoir of molten rock.  The end of
a lava tube is present here, and appears to head off east into the
black rock wall.  The tube is blocked by a wall of fire, however.
Fueled by no discernable source, the fire is probably magical in
nature, but still feels just as hot and looks just as deadly.  No other
exits are apparent, making the only other exit from this area by way of
the fire lake.

287.short: ...You're on a rock cave, by a lake of fire.
287.long:
Many loose rocks cover the ground, making the surface of this cave
difficult to walk upon.  The statues of several people are here, all
facing different directions.  A few steps away, a squarish hole descends
into the rock.  A peg moored in the rock a few feet from the hole has
a rope tied to it, the other end dropping through the hole.  Floating
rocks pass by on a sea of lava to the north, or you can go farther into
the cave to the south.

288.long:
The statues of many men and women stand here, each with a look of
complete terror frozen on their faces.  The place is dark, but still
somewhat lit by the orange glow of magma from the fire sea.  Chunks of
grayish stone lay strewn all over the ground, causing you to have to
watch your step.  You wonder morbidly if any of the rocks are the
broken limbs of the statues.   The only exit is back toward the
beginning of this cave, to the north.

289.long:
This chamber has four square, smooth walls, and was definitely man
made.  Torches set into holders along the walls light the room.  Murals
and tapestries spaced along the walls show various events in religious
history, or portray holy symbology.  The missing piece in the floor
above is here in the center of the room.  The monks must close this
place up during periods of disuse, or more likely, when Khalas is about
to erupt.  You can climb up a rope hanging down from an opening in
the ceiling, or head into an adjoining chamber to the west.

290.long:
These series of torchlit chambers are used by the Brotherhood of
Fire, presumably as a retreat of sorts, or perhaps as a place to hold
ritual ceremonies.  In this particular chamber, the walls and even
the ceiling are decorated with murals and tapestries which portray
famous historic events of the Realm.  In the center of the room are a
number of stone benches, arranged in two concentric circles.  There are
doorways leading into other chambers to the east and west.

291.long:
This chamber is part of many which the monks of fire use and maintain
for their own purposes.  Glowing runes cover this entire room from top
to bottom, but no other visible clue to the function of this area is
available.  Other than these magical decorations, the room is totally
bare, and the only exit is back to the east.
291.item: on the glowing, rune covered floor.

292.long:
This area is an extension of the small cavern to the west, but the
entire north wall has opened up to reveal a sea of molten rock.  This
lake of fire is glowing bright yellow and orange, and the heat from it
is staggering, even from this distance.  Many large pieces of rock are
floating on the lake.  The lake is slowly eating away at the chunks,
and every now and then one disappears completely into the seething
magma, but they remain mostly solvent.  A few of them pass close
enough for you to jump on top, although a few thousand reasons come to
your mind why you would want to avoid doing just that.  The floor here
is smooth and flat, the continuity broken only by a man made staircase
descending down in the direction of the fire sea.
292.item: at the head of the stairs.

293.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
293.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is next to a small cavern, set into the
northwest part of the fire sea.

294.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
294.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is near a shore which leads up to a tunnel
opening.

295.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
295.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is not by anything you can safely jump onto.

296.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
296.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is near a rocky shore, on which is an opening
to a dark tunnel.

297.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
297.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is not by anything you can safely jump onto.

298.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
298.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is not by anything you can safely jump onto.

299.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
299.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is near the outer edge of the lake, near an
entrance to a lava tube, inside of which you can see a blazing fire.

300.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
300.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is just close enough to jump to a rocky shore
on which the blazing end of a lava tube opens up.

301.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
301.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is near a cave which extends a ways into the
south wall of the cavern.

302.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
302.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is not by anything you can safely jump onto.

303.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
303.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is not by anything you can safely jump onto.

304.short: ...You're afloat on a rock in a lake of lava.
304.long:
The rock is large and stays relatively stable, as long as you don't
move around too much.  The bottom of the rock should be burning your
shoes to a crisp, and the heat from the surrounding magma should be
unbearable, but the heat has somehow been reduced to tolerable levels,
although such magic is not known to exist.  The rock is slowly floating
clockwise around the huge cavern which houses the fire lake.  At this
point in its journey, it is near a small cavern, set into the southwest
part of the fire sea.

305.long:
Grey stone walls still stand sturdy in this room, but the ceiling has
long since crumbled into pieces of rubble, now strewn around the floor.
Outside this old structure, blue flames rage in a violent tempest.  To
the south, a staircase leads upward, but is blocked by a heavy iron
portcullis.  The only other exit is through a doorway to the west, over
which strange glyphs are inscribed.

306.long:
Hard, grey stone comprises this long viaduct.  Stone pillars, most of
them broken or crumbled, line the edges of the walkway.  The path
extends as far as you can see to the west, and up to a crumbling old
building to the east.  All other directions are filled with the raging
firestorm that covers all of Acheron.  The flames, blue in color limit
your vision to a couple of feet, but looking into them occasionally
catches you a glimpse of the fire spirits which are often found in
magical fire.

307.long:
Many of the pillars at this point in the walkway have been completely
broken off, leaving small circular chunks torn out of the viaduct.  The
storm has grown more turbulent here than to the east, whipping the blue
flames around with such force that they now begin to encroach upon the
available walking space.  The path continues to the east and the west.

308.long:
This stone path hangs suspended in the middle of an inferno.  A furnace
of red flames almost completely engulfs the walkway, leaving you a very
narrow space in the middle of the bridge in which to walk comfortably.
Just to the west, what was once a stone room, or tower, has managed to
keep most of its walls, and offers some shelter, or you can follow the
path back to the east.

309.long:
This place was once a stone battlement.  The parapet has only been
slightly worn down by the storm, and while the walls are not very high,
they still stand strong, and make for good protection from the storm.
The red flames can not wash over the surface of the stone here, but you
can hear them howling above you, perhaps in frustration.  Grey, stone
paths lead off to the north and east.

310.long:
Much of the grey road has been worn away at the edges by the tempest.
The path has narrowed much from what it was to the southeast and now
looks as rough and jagged as a mountain ledge.  The firestorm blazes
hues of brilliant orange, and streaks of fiery rain come from above.
The fire is magical in nature and does not actually burn.  Any surface
it hits causes the flame to vanish, but when it contacts any part of
your unprotected skin, even though it does not do any damage, the pain
is considerable.  You can reach a tower, still mostly intact, to the
south, or continue on to the north.

311.long:
The condition of the walkway here is very poor.  Holes in the path
go directly through the stone, permitting the flames to gush up through
the openings and create obstacles you must go around.  The firestorm
rages in continual fury and orange rain still descends from the skies
in painful, blazing streaks.  You can often catch a glimpse of a fire
spirit, flying out in the storm.  You can make your way along this
grey road to the north or south.

312.long:
Bright yellow fireballs descend from the sky.  They often hit you and
although they are mostly insubstantial, they do carry some force behind
them.  The pain and irritation from the storm is causing you to become
extremely angry.  The stone here is almost completely gone.  The path
looks so unstable that you do not understand what is keeping it from
falling into the fiery abyss below.  You can make your way across a
tiny strip of road and into a sturdier looking tower to the north, or
head south toward more solid ground.
312.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

313.long:
This area is what remains of a stone battlement.  The fortified walls
have been completely worn away, but the floor is in relatively good
shape, and provides at least some protection from the flames.  The
tempest is now a glowing white, and although nothing falls from the
skies, the heat has grown much worse.  You can leave this tower across
the shaky remains of the road to the south, or the road to the east.

314.long:
This chunk of road is nothing more than a ledge.  To the east, it ends
in a wall of glowing white fire.  Pain which was becoming marginally
tolerable has doubled in intensity.  Hungry white flames scour the area
in a fury of fiery consumption.  Any place the flames manage to reach
your skin is agony.  This road was heading to the east, but as far as
you can tell, this is the end of it.  The road may conceivably continue
within jumping distance, but the only way to find out is to risk almost
unbearable pain followed, with any luck, by a quick death.  The only
sane exit is to the west.

315.long:
Before you stands the Citadel of Fire.  The structure is made of the
same grey stone that is found in the rest of Acheron, but the material
shows no signs of wear.  The building is wide and circular.  No windows
or other openings save the one door are visible.  The firestorm rages
all around you still, but the white flames apparently may not approach
the citadel.  An entire elemental army would be hard pressed to break
into this fortress, much less get here in the first place.  Other than
the doorway, there are no visible exits, but you believe the road to
the west, on the other side of the storm, is still standing.

316.long:
This room is spacious and mostly unadorned.  An immense carpet covers
the circular floor, offering refuge from the hard stone.  Several hand
carved, uncomfortable looking chairs lie strewn about, marking this
place as either a waiting room or a place to hold informal meetings.
Closing your eyes you can almost see the great Alandra and Maruk here,
perhaps contesting with Oreth and Zoth over some issue of importance to
the Realm.  You realize with some pride that just the act of being here
makes you their equal.  A staircase at the far perimeter of the room
leads down to lower levels.

317.long:
A single wall of bright, white light encircles the room.  The light
pulses and glows with the intensity of direct sunlight, and is nearly
painful to look at.  In the center of the room, set into the floor, is
a monstrous fire gem.  The gem takes in the light and prismatically
reflects it into shards of color which strike the ceiling and floor of
the room.  The brilliant jewel is mesmerizing, and you find yourself
stepping closer to take a better look at it, but the sweltering heat
which it radiates keeps you at bay.  The room is otherwise unadorned,
and staircases lead both up and down.

318.long:
This chamber is alive with sparks of orange fire.  Tiny pinpoints of
orange light dance atop the black floor, wall, and ceiling of this
circular room.  The sparks do not burn or sting to the touch but merely
cause the skin to tingle wherever they contact your skin.  An enormous,
round, black bed resides in the center of the room.  You wonder at the
stories this comfortable old bed would tell if it could.  Spiraling
staircases at the perimeter of the room lead both up and down.

319.long:
Sheets of flame cover this entire chamber.  The fire burns in an
aggressive manner, hissing and roaring as it shoots as high as your
waist.  Although the flames do not burn, they fill you with a restless
energy.  Your pulse and respiration quicken and you feel nearly drunk
with power.  A single grey pillar of stone rises up just out of the
flames in the center of the room, the resting place of the Talisman of
Fire.

320.long:
You are far out into open desert.  Giant sand dunes lie in every
direction, and each one presents a difficult hike to the top.  The
wind is fairly active this deep in the desert, and stirs minor
sandstorms which bite your skin and sometimes temporarily blind
you.  You can go in any direction, and every direction seems as good
as the next.
320.item: where it isn't supposed to be.  Please notify the SysOp.

321.long:
The ground is cracked and rocky.  Scrub brush and grasses sparsely
cover the area, offering shade and shelter for small desert creatures.
A few stout cacti are growing here and off in the distance.  A desert
bird flies far above, probably scanning his territory for vulnerable
prey.  The heat persists to slowly bake the ground, and you with it.
The grey skies are not very cheerful, but they do provide shelter from
the sun, at least.  To the south and east, steep mesas and ravines
prevent exploration.  The main road, however, is just off to the north,
and there is more desert to the west.

322.long:
The desert floor is dry and brittle.  In many places, the banks of
dry stream channels from past runoffs trip your footing.  The burrow
holes of small rodents are also becoming something to watch for as you
journey through this area.  Some vegetation is present in the form of
cacti, sagebrush, and scrub brush, but they are pretty few and far
between.  You are unable to proceed any farther to the north and east
due to inhospitable desert terrain, but the main road is just to the
south, and more friendly desert continues to the west.

323.long:
The ground is soft and sandy here, and as you are finding out, quite
treacherous.  Patches of quicksand are becoming major annoyances, and
you have already sunk up to your knee in one of them.  The ground
becomes far too unstable off to the northeast, where the quicksand is
so deep as to likely be fatal, but you can reach more solid ground to
the west and south.

324.long:
You're on a wide ledge, caught between a high canyon to the west, and
a tall mesa to the east.  Shrubs and bushes are growing fairly well
here, along with many cacti, possibly due to increased runoff from the
mesa.  Small, spindly spiders have made homes in many of the bushes,
their webs spun inside the branches to catch the insects the lizards
miss.  This arid region continues to the north and south.

325.long:
Dry, rocky terrain extends in all directions.  Sagebrush and other dry
vegetation is strewn lightly about.  The plant life here is generally
very scarce, but the reptiles and small desert rats are more popular
than one would think this land could support.  Some mineral deposits
show themselves in streaks of orange and grey, but nothing of any real
value.  To the west, a rock ledge juts out over the canyon floor.  The
main road is just to the south, and other areas of the desert are
reachable to the north and east.

326.long:
As you walk across this silent terrain, small creatures scatter for
their hiding spots.  Every now and then you catch a glimpse of a desert
rat heading for his borrow, or a lizard scrambling around the other
side of a rock.  This dry, rocky terrain is a natural place for snakes
to reside, and you sometimes hear the rattlers, so you stay on your
guard.  A short, but impassable dropoff lies to the west, forcing you
to go around.  To the south, the desert grows less rocky, becoming more
populated with sand, and to the east this dry terrain stretches on.
The main road is just to the north.

327.long:
The ground here is sandy and pleasant to walk upon.  Tracks across the
sand tell stories of the many battles fought here.  Some beetle tracks
meet and end at a line of lizard footprints in one place, while another
has the tracks left by a sidewinder converging upon a desert rat.  To
the south, the desert holds more sand still, and sand dunes heavily
cover that region.  The north and west seem to hold more sturdy
portions of the desert.

328.long:
Large sand dunes begin in this area and extend far to the south and
east.  A decent breeze is blowing here, cooling you off, but at the
expense of sand in your face.  These dunes are turning out to be
formidable natural obstacles.  The climb to the top of one is anything
but easy in this climate.  Having your feet regularly sinking a foot
into loose sand in addition to having to withstand this sweltering
heat is enough to make anyone swear up a storm.  Surveying the south
and east, you figure between the wind and heat in those directions,
you would become completely lost in the dunes.   West are more sand
dunes, and the desert flattens out to the north.
328.item: buried halfway in a sand dune.

329.long:
Sand dunes lie beneath ashen skies in every direction.  Toward the
south and east, these giants of the desert become larger, and the wind
is slowly moving them across the land, creating nasty sand storms in
the process.  You figure you could make it that way, but you are not
sure you want to go that deep into the open desert.  North and west
offer more hospitable looking dunes.

330.long:
This region is filled with small sand dunes, which grow larger as they
continue to the south.  The sand is very fine here, and small gusts
of wind are easily able to shift it around.  You can see a large desert
bird circling far above, scanning the sand for likely victims.  The
desert levels out to the north, and more dunes can be reached to the
south, west, and east.

331.long:
A slight updraft is noticeable here at the edge of this canyon, due to
the ascending, warmer air from the bottom.  A few desert birds are
using the updraft here to their advantage, effortlessly looking for
food as they soar through the canyon.  Looking north, through waves of
heat, you can see the city of Avernus jutting out over the canyon
floor, safe upon a wide ledge.  To the south, you are able to see the
beginnings of some small sand dunes.  More level, although rockier,
portions of the desert lie to the east and west.

332.short: ...You're in a desert, on a ledge.
332.long:
This rock juts out a good distance over the canyon floor.  The view is
spectacular.  To the south and north, canyon walls a short way off show
layers of colorful strata, and directly across the canyon to the west,
you can see the city of Avernus.  The city is on an overhang remarkably
similar to this one, so much so that if the canyon were to somehow be
closed up, the two ledges would exactly interweave.  The only exit is
to the east.

333.short: ...You're at the rim of a desert canyon.
333.long:
This region holds a number of thriving cacti, but no other vegetation.
A large antpile rises up from the ground a few feet ahead of you,
worker ants streaming in and out of the entrance.  Looking to the
south, the canyon opens up and extends almost as far as you can see in
this pale realm.  To the north, unless it is a mirage, you could swear
you see a lush oasis.  More desert is accessible to the east and west.

334.long:
Palm trees enclose this place in a circle, standing guard against
desert storms as they gather around a large waterhole.  Many kinds of
plants and insects live here, and although it is not by any means a
jungle, it seems like paradise compared to the rest of the desert.
Large sand dunes begin off to the west, and even larger, more
dangerous ones to the north and west, but to the south the ground
becomes more firm.

335.long:
Large hills of sand begin here and get even larger to the north and
west.  There is a skull of some unfortunate desert animal half buried
in a dune.  The sand and sun have been at it for some time, leaving it
quite clean and polished.  Morbidly you wonder if the rest of it is
still attached, underneath.  Off to the east, unless the heat deceives
your eyes, is a green oasis.  Whatever the skeleton was in life, it
didn't have much farther to go.  To the south you can see the desert
reach the end of a canyon.  A journey to the north and west looks
feasible, but you doubt you will be able to accurately judge your
direction if you proceed that way.

336.long:
This is one of the far ends of the canyon running through the Realm.
It opens up just a few steps away from you and continues to widen as it
jaggedly heads off to the south.  The desert floor is undergoing a
bizzare change, here.  To the east, the sand and rocks have the normal
hues of yellow and brown, but to the west, the desert turns dark grey,
even black.  The floor here is something of a mixture of both, and
looking south, you can see that the darkness seems restricted to the
west side of the canyon.  toward the south are large sized sand dunes,
and to the east and west, the land contains vastly different deserts.

337.long:
More of the flat, dry landscape that makes up most of this desert
stretches out here as well.  Cacti stand still as paul bearers,
continuing to deplete their water supply as they silently wait for the
leaden skies to dole out more drops of life.  The desert grows dark and
ominous to the west as the black landforms resulting from the nearby
volcano become more popular.  Small sand dunes begin to the south, and
the desert floor meets the end of a large canyon to the east.

338.long:
Sand is everywhere.  Blankets of fine grains cover the area in hues
of golden yellow.  A few small dunes rise up from the surface, and
many more beyond that to the south, but this area is mostly level.
The tracks of many camels, no doubt a caravan, extend off to the
south, probably on their way to some secret water hole.  To the
north, the desert ground becomes hard and level, and the east holds
more dunes.  Westward, the desert landscape turns dark and gloomy,
the volcanic influences increasing nearer the slopes of Khalas.

339.long:
Very large sand dunes dominate this area.  On one nearby dune, the
tips of palm trees are sticking out through the sand, perhaps a
buried oasis.  Proof enough that the wind is a destructive force,
adding yet another chance factor in the struggle for life here.  You
can make out the volcano, Khalas, from here, although barely.  In the
deep desert to the south and west, though, you doubt you will even
have that leviathan as a landmark by which to travel.  The north
and east also contain more dunes, less dangerous than the others.

340.long:
Two large buildings dominate this section of the city.  The Warrior's
Guild, to the south, and the Magic User's Guild, to the north.  The two
houses provide a place to buy supplies and visit with others of one's
elemental concentration, and as a result are very popular places.  To
the east is the city square, and a residential area lies off to the
west.

341.long:
Weapons and armor of all sorts line the walls.  Some of them are new,
and some slightly used, but all of them are in good shape.  The rest of
the room is occupied by some comfortable chairs and tables, giving the
room a friendly atmosphere.  The shopkeeper comes toward you as you
enter the store.  Smiling, he shakes your hand and leaves you to
browse the stock.

342.long:
Jars and potions and strange objects fill this cluttered room.  Making
your way past odd looking plants and ducking around shelves of spell
components, you make your way to what serves as a main counter.  An old
lady introduces herself to you as Dara and offers to show you what she
has available for sale.

400.long:
Two great, gushing fountains of water shoot high into the air and
shower this place with constant rain, soon soaking you from head to
foot.  A few inches of water flow across the stone floor, and finally
drain at the edges of the portal.  Regarding the land beyond the
delimiting fountains, you can see a valley of verdant marsh which
eventually turns into a large river.  A well worn path leads east
just beyond the gateway into the fen below, or you can head back west
toward Crossroads.

401.short: ...You're on the outskirts of a marsh.
401.long:
The ground here is solid and damp, but not flooded.  The entire area is
something of a grassland, although during rains it would certainly flood.
High mountains rise in all directions but the south, enclosing this
grassy region in a well protected valley.  A healthy breeze is blowing
in from the south, and sending waves through the high grasses.  The
ground becomes submerged in that direction, but still shallow enough to
venture onto.

402.long:
Dense vegetation thrives here, in the flooded ground.  The water comes
up to your shins, and the soil underneath is soft, soggy mud.  The air
is humid and filled with the musky smell of peat, and insects are
everywhere.  You can discern the gateway to this Realm just a short way
up a gentle hill, and a trail beginning to the west takes you there.
The water becomes too deep for you to travel to the south, however you
can proceed into more marsh to the east, or into a vast grassland to
the north.

403.long:
Cypress trees enclose this place and shade it almost completely from
the sun.  The trees grow on a shore which circles a deep pond in the
center of the clearing.  You can hear the constant, rhythmic croaking
of the frogs that live around this pond, and occasionally see them
splashing about.  Mosquitoes and gnats are also around, taking advantage
of the placid water.  The only exit is to the south.
403.item: on the shore of the pond.

404.long:
Mud squirms and slides under your feet as you walk through this region,
and you have to watch your balance to keep from slipping.  Tiny bubbles
of air surface and pop in the footprints you leave behind and generate
curious noises.  The mud is everywhere, and even continues up the sides
of the mountains bordering to the north and west.  A trek north will
take you into a large clearing, or you can head east into more marsh.

405.long:
The water is only about a foot deep here, helping to speed your
progress.  You occasionally run into a sinkhole every now and then,
however, so you take it slow.  Reeds and cattails spring up in bunches
all around, and brightly colored dragonflies can often be seen zipping
noisily about.  High mountains confine your journey to the west, toward
the beginning of the Realm, or south into more swamp.

406.long:
Murky water easily reaches your waist here, and the muck at bottom
offers little or no traction.  You are keeping careful track of your
possessions, knowing that if you drop one, that is the last you are
likely to see of it.  Walking through this area is thus extremely time
consuming, not to mention dangerous.  Crocodiles thrive in this sort of
place, and are next to impossible to see until they're right on you.
A high tree-covered bank to the west has kept you safe from surprise
attacks so far, and you continue to stick close to it.  You can wade
out into higher areas to the north and south, or head east into still
deeper water.
406.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

407.long:
Water lilies lay atop the surface of the water, providing a floating
waystation for frogs on the move.  The waterline reaches your knees in
the middle of this area, but only manages to cover your feet where the
grasses poke through on the outskirts.  You make a point to check the
surrounding water every couple of moments, as crocodiles and water
snakes are fond of these regions.  Mountains block your way to the
south, but you can continue to traverse this swamp in all other
directions.
407.item: barely visible under the cloudy water.

408.long:
The water here is slowly flowing to the east, probably due to the
mountain streams and runoffs which raise the level of the swamp.  You
are already chest deep in the water, and to the east it becomes even
deeper.  A journey in that direction will necessitate first climbing
to higher ground, but it is possible.  The mountains to the north and
south begin to narrow into a small canyon as they head farther east.
There is no more room to travel northward, but you can still tread
through the water farther to the south.  Also, going west, you can
reach more shallow sections of swamp.
408.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

409.long:
The surface of the water reaches about chest height here, and continues
to deepen toward the east.  A waterfall cascades down the side of the
south mountain and into the water a few steps away.  The swamp has
something of a current to the east at this point, probably due to
drainage from waterfalls like this one.  To that direction, you can
climb out of the water onto the south bank and follow the flow, and
west will take you into a more shallow area.  The mountainsides here
begin to converge into a small canyon as they head to the east.  The
southern ones are so close as to prevent going that way, but you can
still tread a short distance north.
409.item: where it shouldn't be.  Please inform the SysOp.

410.long:
The swamp water here is too deep for you to wade through, but you are
managing to travel well enough upon a narrow section of land running
adjacent to the north mountain.  The murky water is flowing toward the
east, steadily picking up speed and turning into a full fledged river.
A breeze blows in from that direction, gently rocking the reeds and
cattails growing near the side of the water.  The air smells somewhat
of peat and other swamp plants, but is mostly clean and pure.  You can
head along with the current to the east, where this path widens, or to
the west, where the path disappears and the only passage is through the
water.

411.long:
Cattails and reeds line the edges of this swamp.  Mosquitoes are all
around, as are dragonflies, excitedly zipping about on usual insect
business.  The high water slowly winds its way east and will eventually
transform into a small canyon river, losing much of this muddiness in
the process.  For now, you are making your way along an overgrown,
narrow strip of land between the high water and the south mountain.
This walkway vanishes to the west, however, and you will have to get
your feet wet to head any farther in that direction.  Eastward, this
path widens out and forms the banks of the canyon river.

412.short: ...You're on the north bank of a river.
412.long:
Shrubs and bushes grow all around the river's edge, taking advantage of
the unlimited supply of water.  The few open areas which do reach the
